Another feature of the integrated faring not mentioned: flight of the booster alone without payload or a second stage is viable. That opens two possibilities.
As mentioned in the video, Falcon 9 was designed to fit down a highway and Neutron will do away with that, as Neutron is intended to be launched from the factory. It doesn't have to be constrained to there. The booster alone with a partial load of fuel should be able to relocate itself from anywhere in the world to anywhere else in the world with a suitable landing pad autonomously. Modern transport airlines are not constrained by ground transportation, and have grown massive once freed from that limit. The same could be true of boosters that can move themselves. They can launch anywhere the ground support is provided because the booster can move itself there.
The other opportunity is a much higher performance out of a return to launch site mission if the two portions are separated. The booster could land at a down-range turnaround site. No fuel has to be carried aloft and accelerated for the boost back burn. Since most launch sites send the rocket downrange over the ocean, this could be a dedicated island turn-around facility. After boosting the second stage up, the booster could land with reentry and landing only burns on the island. Then with a re-fuel it could come back to the original launch site with a fresh partial load of fuel.
Taken to the extreme and with appropriately spaced facilities around the world, such a booster could just keep circling the globe launching to the east, landing and taking off again to the east from a down-range facility.

Good luck to RL on the Neutron rocket but not at all convinced they will make a carbon fiber/resin cryogenic tanked rocket reusable & will likely abandon that direction for steel/ alloy tanks once the reality of the materials technology challenge comes into focus. The vehicle will likely require some kind of external ablative compound or shielding to prevent breakdown of the resin matrix, but sands that the inter-lamina stress fractures will be extreme transitioning from cryogenic state to high aero-thermal heating loads on renetry.  I also have to critique the product launch video and the demonstration of the impact testing on the different materials, looks impressive to the lay person but people who do actual engineering know a: Carbon fiber composite damage often happens in the inter-lamina regions and isn't visible externally b: The demonstration would look totally different if the materials were brought down to cryogenic temperatures (which is the operational condition BTW). So in effect it proved nothing of real engineering value, I think if they created a set of thin walled tanks filled them all with LN2 and hit them we would get a good demonstration of the limitation of CF composites for cryogenics.

23:30 интересно, ноги действительно могут быть подобием крыльев, например туда можно присоединить элероны и разную авиационную механику и посмотреть улучшит ли это управление, и можно ли использовать полоски опор как крылья. Опустошенную голову ракеты, которая выпустила свою полезную нагрузку, можно использовать как руль в хвосте -- не зря там стоят эти плоскости для руления под самой макушкой ракеты. Низ ракеты будет намного тяжелее верха, особенно в стадии посадки. Как я понял что зад ракеты будет обтекаемым и достаточно горячим, так-как при входе в атмосферу там будет и трение воздуха, и работа горелок двигателя, поэтому они используют немного керамической плитки. Основание ракеты будет действительно тяжелым - устойчивым иными словами.

Я описывал такой вариант ракеты в твиттере одного известного человека, и это была своего рода фантазия. Это был отдельный путь без стали, с минимальной инфраструктурой и без потери обтекателя. Я думал идея излишне новаторская, чтобы кто-то воспринял её всерьёз, но в наше время случайно пришедшие в голову идеи имеют шанс не утонуть в океане забвения, а быть подхваченными теми группами людей, которые реально способны  их применить использовать. Ну как минимум можно получить чувство удовлетворения. Так что если есть хорошие идеи, которые вам не нужны и которые вы никогда не используете, попробуйте делиться ими в интернете. Даже Ютуб часто может воплотить хорошую идею, если вы напишете её в службу поддержки.

Interesting point about the aerodynamic loading - wonder if they will have any issues because they need to open the fairings early to launch the 2nd stage - will see in a few years. It's not a showstopper if that is an issue they can switch to have the fairings on the second stage and just throw them away.
And other very interesting point was about the cost of rockets hardware vs cost of the infrastructure and labor required to launch - for a small rocket the vehicle cost is quite small but the infrastructure and organisational effort to launch it are almost as much as for a much larger rocket.
By going to the bigger machine you launch way more payload and earn more money but the organisational costs stay about the same your overall efficiency in terms of cost per KG to orbit improves.
With the electron the cost per KG to orbit is over $20000 per kg so very hard to compete with rideshare that is less than 1/5th of that cost.
With falcon 9 people incorrectly say the booster costs like 30million the 2nd stage costs 10 million the the fairings cost 6 million and that is how they think the cost of the rocket works out - when really the rocket hardware is maybe only 2/3 of the costs. They forget about the labor the barges the trucks and ships and the manufacturing facility and all those other costs other than the rocket it's self.

It's fascinating to hear how radically different Peter's design mentality is from Elon's. SpaceX and Starship are pushing the limits of everything from their launch pad to engine performance, while Rocket Lab and Neutron are removing the launch infrastructure almost entirely and using engines with as much margin as possible. Both companies are being driven by similar engineering constraints and ideals, but are going in completely different directions to achieve their goals.

I was interested to note that the conversation once again subtly slide over the question of the return-to-launchsite parameters.  

My take on it was that RocketLab are looking at a significantly different launch trajectory than previous standard rockets and flights.
In order to get the First-Stage home in the manner they have outlined, with the fairing system described - then the rocket First-Stage would need to have a much more vertical flight profile. With a lot less horizontal velocity added.
So with a much more efficient/effective Second-Stage, deployed significantly higher than normal, almost all of the horizontal velocity would be added by the second stage.
It is much easier to add horizontal velocity above the atmosphere than in it, so give that job to the second stage.

The First-Stage would effectively just free fall back to its launch point. (sort of)
And this flight-profile off-loads a lot of the loads on the first stage, as the high speed trauma it endures on reentry isn't from the fall, but from the horizontal speed of being thrown down range.
Freefall might be 4,000 kph, while horizontal velocity is closer to 7,000+ kph. Nearly double the speed - and therefore 4 times the energy.

It's interesting, because Rocket Lab is tackling the next gen rocket in largely the opposite way of SpaceX. In fact, it's crazy how diametrically apposed their ideas are.

RocketLab want light structure and simple engines, SpaceX is developing a heavy structure and complex engine.
RocketLab want to put the launch infrastructure into the rocket, SpaceX wants to put the rocket infrastructure into the launch tower.
RocketLab want to build a medium launch rocket because that's where the market is for the forseable future, SpaceX want's to build a new heavy launch vehicle to create new markets.
RocketLab want's to make the first stage the most capable vehicle with a light weight second stage, SpaceX want's to make the second stage the most capable vehicle with a (relatively) simple first stage.

While Neutron and Starship won't be competing with each other, it will be interesting to see who actually has the strategy right for the next gen of space.

I just love this rocket and I want to see some more details. Some points that I'd love to see covered:
- Peter talked about a hot outer skin as thermal protection. Would love to know if he's considered active cooling (using methane as a coolant)?
- Its not just the landing feet, its also the part of the lower body that (if you believe the CGI) has a convex surface towards the airflow. More outer skin, or carbon foam?
- So you have an umbilical from the launch pad. Does the umbilical move to where the rocket lands, or (I think more likely) do they use a crane (or lifting vehicle) to move the rocket into position?
- Integrating the second stage + payload would presumably mean a mobile crane. But you can't close the fairings completely because you've got lift cables in the way. How does the process complete?
- Still not quite comfortable with using a whole Archimedes' engine for the second stage. If it has to be throttled down, then presumably its not optimal mass wise. Plus where does the efficiency go with throttling down?
- Is there still a use for electric pumps in terms of feeding the gas generator and making startup simpler?
- Getting the methane to evaporate in the cooling channels (so it can be guaranteed to be a gas at the injector) requires a thermal balance. Doesn't this restrict throttling?
- I don't necessarily follow Peter's logic about his market. He seems to be relying on large constellations. I'm skeptical about the viability of comms constellations but leaving that aside, if the payload you are sending into orbit is just multiples of the same satellite, then you need a really cost effective launch to compete with much larger rockets. Cost per unit of theoretical mass may not be the most valid metric at times.. but when you are sending lots of the same satellite? Also how much delta-v is left over in the second stage for multiple relights?
- Oh and further to the question about moving the rocket into position, is there a separate launch and landing pad? It occurs to me that the former needs fixing lightning diversion. Hard to land amongst that.

I used to work at a ship construction site. Majority of the shipping modules they built they shipped by barge because they were too large to ship by land (truck). However, whenever they could ship smaller modules they always shipped by land. The cost of an oversized truck, plus multiple police escorts (including state changes), plus cost of closing down roads temporarily and/or removing poles along with a bunch of other costs etc was still significantly cheaper than sending by barge. I was absolutely dumbstruck when I heard that it was costing the company $30,000 per day just to keep the barge berthed at their own port. Literally sitting at a port doing absolutely nothing costing the company $30,000 per day. And the company still had to pay to have the port dredged as a separate cost. I just couldn't, and still don't, understand it. It would cost over $1 million to ship by barge (not including costs of staying at port) compared to around $100k to ship by land.
